Comte</tei-persName>, the other to the illustrious and unfortunate traveller <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor Jacquemont</tei-persName>.
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      To obtain the labour of a slave, says the learned jurist, a master pays him one small part in provisions or in clothing, and the other part in blows of the whip. We cannot consider
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-note data-origname="note">
    (1) There is an error in the figure; at the Martinique one can hardly find to-day 1000 fr. for a slave. (Editor’s note.)
  </tei-note>

  <tei-pb n="28" facs="v1n7f28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      what is acquired with this last kind of money otherwise than we consider the profits made by the individuals who go to rob travellers upon the high-roads. Thus, when we grant a monopoly to the commodities sold by owners of men, to the prejudice of proprietors who sell the same commodities, but who cause their lands to be cultivated only by free persons, we are in the same case as a man who should refuse to buy merchandise from those who have produced it, and who would buy only stolen merchandise. Such a traffic on the part of an dishonest man would be natural, if the stolen goods were delivered at a much lower price than the current price of commerce; but if thieves, considering the dangers of their profession, demanded a higher price, what should we think of him who gave them the preference? We should think that such a man carries dishonesty even to extravagance. (1)
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    On the 12th of January 1829, Jacquemont wrote to his friend Mr. de Tracy, member of the Chamber of Deputies:
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      I have seen at close hand, at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Rio</tei-placeName>, this horrible traffic carried on there upon an immense scale. I have retained from the sight of these human miseries a feeling of horror which is effaced with difficulty from my terrified mind. Yet he who wills the end wills the means. Say plainly that the slavery of the blacks is the <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">sine qua non</tei-foreign> of the existence of <tei-placeName ref="#BR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Brazil</tei-placeName>, as of European domination in all the lands of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">America</tei-placeName> situated between the tropics, without being very much elevated above the level of the sea.
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      For us in particular, if <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bourbon</tei-placeName> have experienced for some years a movement of prosperity, it is due only to the fact that the connivance of the administrators of these colonies, not to say their open protection, has allowed more cargoes of slaves to be landed there... Say then that the general cry of opinion accuses the colonial administration of a criminal connivance in the trade. Say that you are convinced that they cannot prosper except by the trade, that they cannot even maintain themselves except by continual importations of
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-note data-origname="note">
    (1) <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ch. Comte</tei-persName>, <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Traité de législation</tei-title></tei-bibl>, book 5, chap. xix.
  </tei-note>

  <tei-pb n="29" facs="v1n7f29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      blacks, and that their present prosperity is the highest condemnation of their administration.» (1)
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Blanqui</tei-persName> thinks that there exist means of reconciling, as far as possible, the principles of property, which colonial disorder must not cause to be lost from view, with the question of home consumption, and with that of humanity, higher, more sacred. He announces that he will occupy himself with it on Friday the 9th of January in an approaching lecture.
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    In its next number, the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des colonies</tei-title></tei-bibl> will give the faithful analysis of that lecture.
  </tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="USA" id="USA" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="États-unis." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">UNITED STATES</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

  <tei-div xml:id="SocUSesclavage" id="SocUSesclavage" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Société américaine contre l'esclavage." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">AMERICAN ANTI-SLAVERY SOCIETY</tei-orgName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We have before us the first annual report of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">American Anti-Slavery Society</tei-orgName>, and the speeches delivered at the anniversary meeting, at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Chatham Street Chapel</tei-placeName>, in the city of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">New-York</tei-placeName>, as well as the official papers attesting the labours of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Society</tei-orgName> in its various meetings.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      This <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Society</tei-orgName>, which was constituted at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Philadelphia</tei-placeName>, on the 4th of December 1833, in an assembly composed of sixty-three delegates, representing the various societies of the States of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Maine</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Vermont</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">New Hampshire</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Massachusetts</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Rhode-Island</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Connecticut</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">New-York</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">New-Jersey</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Pennsylvania</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Ohio</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Maryland</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Delaware</tei-placeName>, in the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">District of Columbia</tei-placeName> and the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Territory of Michigan</tei-placeName>, published, after a solemn deliberation which lasted three days, a declaration of principles in which breathe the highest spirit of religion and of philosophy.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      At the anniversary sitting held in 1834, a numerous and distinguished audience was present. Many persons of great talent delivered there very remarkable speeches.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The committee is composed of: MM.
      <tei-list data-origname="list">
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ARTHUR TAPPAN</tei-persName>, president.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">JOHN RANKIN</tei-persName>, vice-president.</tei-item>
      </tei-list>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-note data-origname="note">(1) Correspondence, p. 51.</tei-note>

    <tei-pb n="30" facs="v1n7f30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-list data-origname="list">
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">SAMUEL H. COX</tei-persName>, secretary for foreign correspondence.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">SAMUEL E. CORNISH</tei-persName>.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">JOSHUA LEAVITT</tei-persName>.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">WILLIAM GREEN</tei-persName>, treasurer.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">PETER WILLIAMS</tei-persName> (man of colour).</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">THEODORE WRIGHT</tei-persName>.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">LEWIS TAPPAN</tei-persName>.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">WILLIAM GOODELL</tei-persName>.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ABRAHAM S. COX</tei-persName>, secretary-reporter.</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ELIZAR WRIGHT, JUN.</tei-persName>, secretary for domestic correspondence.</tei-item>
      </tei-list>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      In our next deliveries we shall make known the labours of this honourable society.
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="ColFr" id="ColFr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="Colonies françaises." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

  <tei-div xml:id="Martinique." id="Martinique." data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Martinique." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">MARTINIQUE</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Our correspondent at Saint-Pierre writes to us, dated the 2d of October:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">colonial government</tei-orgName> has publicly carried on a traffic of a new kind, on the 10th of last September. The schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">the Charte</tei-emph>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">captain</tei-roleName> <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Coulin</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">owner</tei-roleName> <tei-persName data-origname="persName">T. P. Ferry</tei-persName>, received on board eight slaves of both sexes, to be conveyed to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Porto Rico</tei-placeName>, on account of an inhabitant of that colony who had purchased them. The boat which brought them on board the schooner the Charte was under the guard of two <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">royal gendarmes</tei-roleName>, and a <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">chasseur of the mountains</tei-roleName>, whom I recognised as the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">orderly</tei-roleName> of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Rosily</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">director-general of the interior</tei-roleName>. The Charte remained two days in the roadstead after the embarkation of the said slaves; and during that time the two gendarmes were stationed on board her. The fact is notorious: every one has seen it here; and people ask for whose benefit this commercial operation has been effected.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="31" facs="v1n7f31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Another letter, dated the 3d of November, expresses itself thus:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        Since the colonial government, in contempt of the laws, sold to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">a certain Mr. Maréchal</tei-persName> slaves who were embarked on the schooner the Charte, as I have already written to you, this infamous traffic is carried on in a frightful manner by private persons who purchase properties in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Porto Rico</tei-placeName>. So soon as a slave displeases, the master has no other means of getting rid of him than to sell him to these new traffickers in human flesh, who carry them to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Porto Rico</tei-placeName> in coasting boats which no one takes the trouble to watch. It is reckoned here, within a month, more than twenty slaves who have gone to recruit the gangs of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Bigue</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Mayagônes</tei-placeName>. Three days ago a boat was to take ten, who were already shut up in the dungeons of an estate at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Rivière-Blanche</tei-placeName>; the manoeuvres of this coaster having roused the vigilance of a customs schooner, the boat could receive only three. Another was about to be embarked, who was found handcuffed in a pirogue, accompanied by his master; but, at sight of the vessel which was to tear him for ever from his native soil, cries of despair broke from him; a struggle ensues between master and slave; the frail pirogue, ill-ballasted, cannot withstand the shock, capsizes, and drags the unhappy handcuffed slave into the depths of the sea. Some maintain that they succeeded in saving him and putting him on board the vessel; others assure us that he was drowned. If I cannot, to-day, give you fuller information on this fact, it is because this wretched master, in concert with those who trafficked with him, has contrived to wrap his actions in a mysterious veil, which I may perhaps succeed in lifting.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        There is tumult and discord in the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">colonial council</tei-orgName>, assembled since the 15th of October. The councillors will not admit the heads of administration to their deliberations, and these pretend, wrongly, to be called to them of right; while the former persist in recognising that prerogative only when they are the bearers of projects of decrees from the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">government</tei-orgName>. The <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName>, having taken the side of his high agents, the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">colonial council</tei-orgName>, rather than suffer itself to be dissolved, has preferred to yield, but under constraint, and with the fixed intention of recording that constraint in its minutes. Two <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">councillors</tei-roleName> have resigned, Messrs. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Maillet</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Vergeron</tei-persName>.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="32" facs="v1n7f32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
  </tei-div>

  <tei-div xml:id="Alger" id="Alger" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Alger." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">ALGIERS</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      An ordinance of the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">lieutenant-general</tei-roleName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Count d’Erlon</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor-general</tei-roleName> of the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">French possessions in the north of Africa</tei-placeName>, decrees that the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">municipal council</tei-orgName> of the city of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Algiers</tei-placeName> shall be composed of the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">mayor</tei-roleName> and nineteen members belonging to the French, Mussulman, and Jewish populations, in the following proportion:
      <tei-list data-origname="list">
        <tei-item data-origname="item">French ..... 10</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">Mussulmans ......6</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">Jews ..........3</tei-item>
      </tei-list>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      There are appointed members of the said council, Messrs. Alphandery, merchant; <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Bonneville</tei-persName>, president of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Colonization Society</tei-orgName>; Bournichon, merchant; Carantène, merchant; Conput, merchant; Duchassaing, proprietor; <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Girot</tei-persName>, president of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Chamber of Commerce</tei-orgName>; Martin, notary; Vialard, proprietor; Urtis, advocate; Achmed-abou-Darla, Ali-ben-Elbahhar, Mohammed-Madani, Kadji-ben-Otsman-Khodja, Ibrahim-ben-Moustapha-Pacha, Joseph-Bacri, proprietor; Léon Durant, merchant; Moise and David Narboni, merchants.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The members of this council are appointed for one year, and may re-enter upon their functions at the expiration of that term.
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="ColÉtr" id="ColÉtr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="Colonies étrangères." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>

  <tei-div xml:id="Antigue" id="Antigue" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Antigue." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">ANTIGUA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We read in the journal of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Antigua</tei-placeName>:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The intelligence which reaches us daily from all quarters confirms the admirable conduct of the newly emancipated. We should be happy to have nothing but praise to bestow; yet it would be unjust not to avow that the patience of a great number of these emancipated persons has been put to a very severe trial, a trial which they have hitherto borne with admirable resignation. Many traits little honourable to certain colonist planters have been related; we shall cite only a small number of these inhuman and ungenerous acts, which do no honour to the conduct of those colonists.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="33" facs="v1n7f33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        On one estate, the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">driver</tei-roleName> has caused to be locked up all the provisions raised in the corners of land cultivated by the emancipated blacks.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «On other properties, subsistence which the law secures to old men has been refused them. A proprietor caused a poor man to be arrested as a vagabond, and shut up in the house of detention, because he had passed the night in the dwelling of his wife attached to the said plantation. This same proprietor, though a magistrate, ordered his keeper to arrest, should he appear upon the estate, a black whom he had driven away because he refused to hire himself out, not being able to handle the hoe. And yet this unhappy man had all he possessed shut up in his hut.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «It would be far too unjust to let the reproaches we have just addressed to a few rest upon all colonists who were former owners of slaves; and it is with very lively pleasure that we render homage to the kindness and conciliatory manners with which a great number of proprietors have treated their labourers.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «After speaking of these vexatious proceedings of the planters, which proceed only from a violent regret at having lost a power without bounds, and from a malevolent intention of driving the unhappy blacks to revolt, we shall point out the necessity of effecting a complete change in the magistracy; or rather, of interposing between the masters and the emancipated blacks new men who are not accustomed to the management of estates and slaves.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>

  <tei-div xml:id="Saint-Christophe" id="Saint-Christophe" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Saint-christophe" data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">ST. CHRISTOPHER</tei-placeName></tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The journal of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Antigua</tei-placeName> relates in the following terms what took place at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName>, on the occasion of the abolition of slavery:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The blacks, undeceived as to their hopes of entire freedom, and having learned that their brethren of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Antigua</tei-placeName> were, on the first of August, to enjoy all the rights of citizens, formed the resolution to work only as men truly free; that is to say, for wages, and with the power of choosing those who were to employ them. They persevered in this disposition notwithstanding two proclamations which the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName> <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mac-Grégor</tei-persName> published to
      </tei-quote>
      <tei-pb n="34" facs="v1n7f34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        recall them to order and enlighten them as to the consequences of their disobedience to the law. It must be avowed, however, in favour of the blacks, that, in the midst of their delusion, they committed no act of violence or revolt, except in one single instance, when the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">lieutenant-governor</tei-roleName> was insulted by a small number; but as it was to be feared that this obstinacy and idleness, if prolonged, might pass into open revolt, the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor-general</tei-roleName> substituted for the slow forms of civil justice the prompt and energetic action of military law. Scarcely was it known that the militia was under arms and the troops ready to march, when the return of a crowd of apprentices to their labour was announced, and the gradual submission of the whole body of the emancipated. The governor, seeing order re-established among the working population, judged it proper to relieve the country from the burdensome restraints of martial law. The proclamation which he then published contained counsels for masters and servants.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «After announcing the submission of the rebels, the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName> exhorted the masters to forget the faults of these misguided men; he granted, in the name of <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">his sovereign</tei-roleName>, an amnesty to all those who are not in the hands of justice. He hopes, says he, that the apprentices will show themselves grateful for this clemency by obeying the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">lieutenant-general</tei-roleName> and the authorities of the colony; and that moreover the proprietors and the first class of society will set the example of submission to the laws, in their own interest, and as an obligation imposed upon all the subjects of <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">H. M.</tei-roleName>
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «One of the causes which have most contributed to irritate the apprentices of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName> is, doubtless, the generosity of five proprietors: Lords <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Combermère</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Rodney</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mrs. Biscon</tei-persName>, and two other persons who have not required apprenticeship from their labourers, and have given them wages; while their companions, free men, groan in the bonds of slavery, ennobled with a new and false title.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «In these passing troubles, five of the newly emancipated have been transported to the establishment of correction, at the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Bernardines</tei-orgName>; and we deplore the death of three of these unfortunate men, killed in the night for not having answered the calls of the sentinels.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The blacks of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName> do not regard the present <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName> as they did his predecessors; they imagine that the king has
      </tei-quote>
      <tei-pb n="35" facs="v1n7f35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        sent him not only to govern the colony, but, in particular, to protect them; and he has, in some sort, confirmed them in that belief by the generous care he has taken to recommend to all a proper conduct towards this population, and by his readiness to listen to their grievances. We are convinced that this simple display of force, and the energetic measures ordered by him whom they regard as their friend, have impressed a far more salutary fear upon the apprentices of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName> than would the slaughter of some hundreds by one who would not bear the same character in their eyes.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName> has caused several of the judgments pronounced against some of these unhappy persons to be revised; the penalties appeared to him far too severe; and it would seem that, in consequence of the firm resolution manifested by him not to tolerate any excessive severity, the amount of punishments inflicted has been very greatly reduced. Some of the most exalted partisans of slavery have manifested their displeasure; but the opinion of such men merits no attention.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The journal concludes thus:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «Although we are persuaded that we shall displease many colonists of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName> in publishing what precedes, we ought not to fail in our duty, while regretting that the occasion should have presented itself. It has not been our intention to insinuate that our neighbours are more unjust than ourselves, or than the inhabitants of the other colonies: no, certainly; but we believe that they are still under the yoke of those absurd and barbarous prejudices, and that they act under the influence of that spirit of hatred and pride engendered by the system of slavery. One shudders at the mere idea of a tribunal composed of men under the empire of passions wholly Creole; of whom the greater number are interested parties, judging those who lately were their slaves.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «It is asserted that two persons who have lately arrived from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Christopher</tei-placeName> at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Antigua</tei-placeName> are charged, in the interest of their fellow-citizens, to study our system of full and entire freedom. It is of good augury, and we sincerely desire that their report may cause apprenticeship to be replaced by entire liberty.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>

  <tei-pb n="36" facs="v1n7f36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

  <tei-div xml:id="Maurice" id="Maurice" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Maurice." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">MAURITIUS</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We have a letter from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Port-Louis</tei-placeName>, dated the 12th of September:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «The order recalling <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Jérémie</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">attorney-general</tei-roleName>, arrived on the 27th of August, and was notified to him on the 29th. The <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName>, charged with making provisional appointments, offered the place of prosecutor and <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">advocate-general</tei-roleName> to Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Prosper d’Epinay</tei-persName>, who accepted only that of advocate-general; but it is the advocate-general who, for the moment, sits on the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Legislative Council of the colony</tei-orgName> and on the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">commission charged with settling the indemnity for the slaves</tei-orgName>. Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">d’Epinay</tei-persName> has refused to accept the functions of <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">attorney-general</tei-roleName> before knowing whether a magistrate will not be sent from <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName>. This case excepted, it is he who will be named to that place, which Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Williams</tei-persName>, substitute of Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jérémie</tei-persName>, occupies provisionally.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «Mr. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jérémie</tei-persName>, who had at once taken his resolution and secured his passage in a vessel bound for <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">London</tei-placeName>, has decided to remain, in order to await the effect of his letters of justification. He is at this moment occupied in circulating an address to the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">king</tei-roleName>, to request that he be reinstated in his functions, as the only man in the colony capable of fulfilling them.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>

  <tei-div xml:id="Sainte-Lucie" id="Sainte-Lucie" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Sainte-lucie." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">ST. LUCIA</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We have a letter from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Castries</tei-placeName>, dated the 1st of November:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «In the first months which followed the emancipation of the slaves, the apprentices seemed disposed to neglect their labour, seeing in it the image of their former condition; but to-day they have returned from their error, and labour prospers. The gangs are in good order; all here is in the greatest tranquillity; the proprietors are satisfied, and I do not despair that the colony will yield more revenue than it has ever yielded.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>

  <tei-div xml:id="Jamaïque" id="Jamaïque" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Jamaïque." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">JAMAICA</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We read in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Watchman</tei-title></tei-bibl>, a journal printed in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Jamaica</tei-placeName>, the following passage on the effect produced in that colony by the great measure for the abolition of slavery:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="37" facs="v1n7f37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «We are happy to announce that the newly emancipated apprentices quietly apply themselves to their ordinary labour throughout all the parishes of the colony.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="NvellesDiverses" id="NvellesDiverses" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="Nouvelles diverses." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    The ministry in England is now definitively constituted. The members of this new cabinet have been chosen from among the most determined opponents of every species of reform. It is the very extreme of retrogression in the old English aristocracy. These are the names:
    <tei-list data-origname="list">
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir Robert Peel</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">First Lord of the Treasury</tei-roleName> and <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Chancellor of the Exchequer</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        The <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Duke of Wellington</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Goulburn</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Secretary of State for the Home Department</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Lord Warncliffe</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Lord Privy Seal</tei-roleName>.</tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Alex. Baring</tei-persName>, president of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Board of Trade</tei-orgName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">The Earl of Rosslyn</tei-persName>, president of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Council</tei-orgName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir George Murray</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Master-General of the Ordnance</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir Edward Knatchbull</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Paymaster-General of the Forces</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Lord Ellenborough</tei-persName>, president of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Board of Control</tei-orgName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Herries</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Secretary at War</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Lord Lyndhurst</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Lord Chancellor</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir James Scarlett</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Chief Baron of the Exchequer</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir Edward Sugdon</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Lord Chancellor of Ireland</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir Henry Hardinge</tei-persName>, first secretary to the Lord Lieutenant.
      </tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">The Earl of Aberdeen</tei-persName>, <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Secretary of State for the Colonies</tei-roleName>.
      </tei-item>
    </tei-list>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    — We read in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Abolitionist</tei-title></tei-bibl> the following extract from a report of the English commissioners to their government:
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      «It is with great regret that we have again to announce the continuance, upon a large scale, of the slave-trade at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">the Gallinas</tei-placeName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jozé de Inza</tei-persName>, captain of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Segunda Socorro</tei-emph>, a slaver lately captured, confessed to the registrar, Mr. Lewis, who questioned him upon the traffic, that three Spanish slavers had taken negroes at the same place, and that a fourth, of the same na-
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-pb n="38" facs="v1n7f38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      tion, was to sail with her full cargo shortly after the departure of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Segunda Socorro</tei-emph>.
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      «These are the names of the first three vessels:
      <tei-list data-origname="list">
        <tei-item data-origname="item">
          The brig <tei-emph data-origname="emph">el Temerario</tei-emph> carried off…………….600 negroes.
        </tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">
          The brig <tei-emph data-origname="emph">la Imperice</tei-emph>......………………………….450
        </tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">
          The schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Segunda Socorro</tei-emph> ……………....507
        </tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">A three-masted vessel, unknown ………….....450</tei-item>
        <tei-item data-origname="item">Total…….807</tei-item>
      </tei-list>
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      «Inza did not hesitate to confess that he had long been engaged in the slave-trade; that he had already made fourteen voyages, the last four to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">the Gallinas</tei-placeName>; and that this was the first time he had been captured.
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
      «The number of slavers taken in the course of the year 1833, and carried into <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Havana</tei-placeName>, is four, all Spanish. They had on board, at the moment of capture, 1,519 negroes; 63 died; the remaining 1,456 were emancipated and restored to liberty.»
    </tei-quote>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    —— In order to show with what activity the slave-trade is still carried on at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Havana</tei-placeName>, the commissioners deputed to that port state, in their report, that in the year 1831 thirty slavers landed their cargoes there; that in 1832 twenty-seven slavers, of which two were <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Portuguese</tei-placeName>, likewise accomplished their voyages; and that a little before the month of October, the date of their last despatch, slavers were continually departing and arriving, which the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Spanish</tei-placeName> authorities protected clandestinely. In a communication addressed by them to the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">English government</tei-orgName> in 1833, they pointed out the schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Printa</tei-emph>, Captain Capo, and the brig <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Plinio</tei-emph>, Captain Ignacio-Calbert, as habitually engaged in the slave-trade. The latter vessel entered the port of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Santiago de Cuba</tei-placeName> after having landed cargo negroes upon the coast. The brig <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Ninsa</tei-emph>, Captain José-Salval, had landed more than 600.
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    In a despatch of the 12th of September 1834, after announcing that 760 negroes had been landed fourteen leagues from the city of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Havana</tei-placeName>, they add that the declaration of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Spanish government</tei-orgName>, touching the traffic in negroes, has been made in so imperfect a manner, and that the precautions of surveillance are so insufficient, that slavers are openly dispatched for the
  </tei-p>

  <tei-pb n="39" facs="v1n7f39" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    ports of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Africa</tei-placeName>, where it is well known they can carry on no legitimate commerce. They indicate several points of the island, and even in the neighbourhood of the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">capital</tei-placeName>, where sheds are constructed for the use of newly landed negroes.
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    —— The <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">correspondent</tei-roleName> at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Hamburg</tei-placeName> publishes a letter from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Copenhagen</tei-placeName>, announcing that the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">King of Denmark</tei-roleName> has issued an ordinance expressly recommending the most perfect equality in regard to the free population of the Danish colonies. All distinctions between whites and men of colour are for ever abolished by this ordinance. All men of colour who shall produce proofs of irreproachable conduct during three successive years shall be restored to freedom, and called to enjoy the same civil and political rights as the white population. This last provision applies likewise to men of colour born out of the colonies.
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    —— The <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> publishes the return of manumissions of slaves, of which official notice has reached the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Department of the Navy</tei-orgName> since the 13th of August 1834. The number of new manumissions granted in the four colonies, <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">French Guiana</tei-placeName>, and <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bourbon</tei-placeName>, amounts to 2,051. And the total number since the end of 1850 amounts to:
    <tei-list data-origname="list">
      <tei-item data-origname="item">14,919, for <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>.</tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">6,251, for <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>.</tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">957, for <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">French Guiana</tei-placeName>.</tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">1,144, for <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bourbon</tei-placeName>.</tei-item>
      <tei-item data-origname="item">TOTAL....... 25,268, for the four colonies.</tei-item>
    </tei-list>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">
    —— One of the noblest characters of the opposition, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Eusèbe Salverte</tei-persName>, the man pre-eminently upright, the devoted friend of every good cause, whom the Paris electors, in a moment of monarchic vertigo, preferred to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Thiers</tei-persName> last June, has just been elected deputy, in spite of ministerial intrigues, by a very large majority, in the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">electoral college</tei-orgName> of the fifth arrondissement of Paris. The cause of the blacks and of the mulattoes, thanks to progress, may reckon upon one zealous defender more in the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Chamber</tei-orgName>.
  </tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-pb n="40" facs="v1n7f40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

<tei-div xml:id="Variétés" id="Variétés" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="Variétés." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">VARIETIES.</tei-head>

  <tei-div xml:id="chapeau-Halgan" id="chapeau-Halgan" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="De m. le gouverneur halgan et de son chapeau, l'un portant l'autre." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">
      OF MR. GOVERNOR HALGAN AND OF HIS HAT, THE ONE SUPPORTING THE OTHER.
    </tei-head>

    <tei-epigraph data-origname="epigraph">
      <!-- je ne sais pas comment encoder des répliques de théâtre-->
    </tei-epigraph>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      All the world knows that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> is <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName> of <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>; but what the world does not yet know is that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> has profoundly reflected upon the representative system, and in particular upon the use of the hat as an instrument of government. Happily there exists in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName> a veritable
      <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl>
      which possesses all the grace and exactness of that of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Madame Agasse, widow</tei-emph>. Happily, too, we have read that journal, which is not a common thing, and we have borrowed from it the interesting particulars which follow:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      OPENING OF THE COLONIAL COUNCIL.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «Conformably to the proclamation of the 1st of October 1834, the members of the colonial council, present in the colony, were assembled a little before noon, in the hall appointed for the sittings...... etc.
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        Mr. the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName>, after having invited the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">councillors</tei-roleName> to take their seats, pronounced, seated and covered, the opening speech.»
      </tei-quote>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We had hitherto known only constitutional kings who deemed it decent and becoming to come and communicate to the representatives of the nation their petty wills, their tender sentiments, their personal joys and satisfactions, their wants of money, and their vows for the prosperity of the country; and to deliver the monarchic rosary at their ease in a comfortable arm-chair, the hands resting on the thigh and an enormous hat upon the head. And what has not been said of that hat? Some maintained it was old and threadbare; others that his majesty wore it awry: these said it was a plumed hat, those a three-cornered hat, a two-cornered hat..... and so on. Such is the lot of the world. For our part, we shall not make so many reflections upon <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName>'s hat; we shall simply say that the only thing which appeared to us worthy of remark in the hat was, that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> wore it upon his head.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="41" facs="v1n7f41" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      One cannot too much admire here the power of great examples. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> said to himself: The politeness of kings consists in speaking with the hat on the head; I am here a little sovereign; therefore, when I go to communicate to the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">colonial councillors</tei-roleName> the ideas which I am supposed to have conceived for the public happiness, I must uncover my heart and cover my head. It seems to me that, if I had had the honour to be a colonial councillor, I should have said to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> what <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Sganarelle</tei-emph> says to <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Géronte</tei-emph> in the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Médecin malgré lui</tei-emph>:
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «Hippocrates says, Mr. <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Governor</tei-roleName>, that we should both keep our hats on.»
      </tei-quote>
      And if <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> had made the slightest observation, I should very quickly have referred him to the chapter on hats; but no: the colonial aristocracy is not so susceptible, at least as to things that come from above; it accepts the superiority of the chief on condition that it may itself make felt its own upon those whom the most miserable prejudice keeps as its inferiors. This pact of servitude makes up, more or less, the whole morality of society; and this is what we have seen admirably characterized in an old English caricature which represents the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">King</tei-roleName> of <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName> giving a kick to his <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">prime minister</tei-roleName>, who passes it on to a member of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Commons</tei-orgName>, who passes it on to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">John Bull</tei-persName>, who, for his part, passes it on to no one. We believe, therefore, that the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">colonial council</tei-orgName> consoled itself for the kick, we mean for the hat-blow of Mr. the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Governor</tei-roleName>, by thinking it might very well return it to others.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> and his hat delivered a discourse in which we admired this passage:
      <tei-q data-origname="q">
        «Tranquillity reigns in all parts of the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">colony</tei-placeName>: I shall devote my care to maintaining order there; the fidelity of the gangs, in difficult circumstances, their attachment to their masters, will be to-day, especially for the metropolis, guarantees of the system of moderation by which they are governed.»
      </tei-q>
      The fidelity of the gangs... Oh! oh! oh! there are no more slaves in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>. There are only workmen, such as we see every day, who labour in workshops! Admirable! What a revolution!
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="42" facs="v1n7f42" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Long live the <tei-bibl type="legal" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Charter</tei-title></tei-bibl>! Long live humanity! Our hearts as citizens have expanded at the sound of this official language. There were even some who were tempted already to envy the lot of those workmen who labour in the workshops of <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>. Unhappily the <tei-bibl type="legal" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Official Journal</tei-emph></tei-title></tei-bibl> contains a certain number of petitions for <tei-emph data-origname="emph">manumission</tei-emph>; and after having read and re-read the discourse, and compared together the first and second page of the journal, we became convinced that the pretended <tei-emph data-origname="emph">workmen</tei-emph> might very well be <tei-emph data-origname="emph">slaves</tei-emph>; or rather, according to the word now agreed upon, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">persons not free</tei-emph>. However, as one must always admire something, we admired the delicacy of language of civilized races and the governmental modesty of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName>.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      What is no less curious is the dialogue established between the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">governor</tei-roleName>, in his opening speech, and the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">colonial councillors</tei-roleName>, in the address in reply to the said speech. You will see that these latter stand less upon ceremony.
      <tei-q data-origname="q">
        «The losses of commerce (<tei-emph data-origname="emph">of commerce!</tei-emph>) will be easily repaired, if the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">fidelity of the gangs</tei-emph> (again) <tei-emph data-origname="emph">is no longer shaken by the contagion of fatal doctrines, the bait of an illusory liberty</tei-emph> (this is too much, even for colonists) and the disappointments of an organized hiring-out, which is still favoured by the absence of any penal provision.»
      </tei-q>
      No: since languages have existed, there has never been so extraordinary a use made of words. <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Slaves shaken by the contagion of fatal doctrines which push them toward an illusory liberty..... and the disappointments of an organized hiring-out, which strike at their fidelity....</tei-emph> This may give an idea of the confusion that reigned at the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Tower of Babel</tei-emph>. The ancients who established slavery at least had logic: they relied upon the law of the stronger, and they applied it without mercy to those who revolted; but they did not complain of revolt. They never constructed syllogisms for slaves, to prove to them that, in breaking their irons, they were running after an illusory liberty. There are people who pretend that these gentle turns of phrase, used to express abuses so melancholy, announce a great improvement. We wish it with all our heart; but for ourselves, we see in it only the desire to preserve, under names less strange, a power of which no one ever strips himself voluntarily, and not the shame of still exercising it.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="43" facs="v1n7f43" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      If you would know what <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> replied to this harsh contradiction of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">colonial council</tei-orgName>, he said:
      <tei-q data-origname="q">
        «I am grateful, and I thank you for the sentiments you express toward me.»
      </tei-q>
      There is really no need: Mr. the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Governor</tei-roleName> is not hard to please. And, in the end, in spite of his formidable cocked hat, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName> is at bottom a worthy man, who knows how to take things as they should be taken. We should not even be astonished if, at the close of his thanks, he rose from his arm-chair and put his hand to his hat, to salute the gentlemen councillors.
    </tei-p>
  </tei-div>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="Chronique" id="Chronique" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head n="Chronique." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">CHRONICLE.</tei-head>

  <tei-div xml:id="politique-euro" id="politique-euro" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head n="Politique européenne.—situation." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">EUROPEAN POLITICS.—THE SITUATION.</tei-head>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Mr. <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Director</tei-roleName> of the
      <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title></tei-bibl>.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
        «Peoples advance slowly, it is true; but still they advance, said <tei-persName data-origname="persName">d'Alembert</tei-persName>, and sooner or later they arrive.»
      </tei-quote>
      — Do what they may, we shall arrive.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The most striking symptom of our time, even amid the confusion of doctrines and principles, is that, willingly or unwillingly, nations desire to govern themselves. There lies the culminating point toward which all their efforts tend to-day; and every thing assures us that they will know how to reach it.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Certain appearances may, here and there, seem vainly to indicate the contrary. The retrograde movement appears, in some quarters, to triumph. Be it as it may, the elements of social progress are so numerous, they act on every side with so much power, the press is so formidable an auxiliary of the future, that there is nothing to fear from the counter-revolutionary efforts which are about to be seriously renewed.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      For you, my friend, the affairs of <tei-placeName ref="#EUR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Europe</tei-placeName> have a double interest: you live among us; you have our concerns at heart because you are enlightened and generous, and because, all things considered, they are yours to-day; but also, in the first place, because you know that every fortunate step accomplished here in favour of our liberty profits <tei-pb n="44" facs="v1n7f44" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>, in the end, universal liberty,—humanity itself,—one of whose dearest branches for you is the race of colour, oppressed in all its shades. Hence, above all, your solicitude; hence the high interest with which you regard the party which, in <tei-placeName ref="#EUR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Europe</tei-placeName>, is for liberty and the common right against every kind of privilege, and which is called the party of movement, in opposition to the party of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">statu quo</tei-emph>, which at any price would maintain what exists, because what exists is its profit.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      You know it: my policy is very simple. I see in our Europe, as in your dear colonies, only slaves and masters, oppressors and oppressed. To put an end to this state of things everywhere,—such is the labour of the movement; to maintain it,—such is that of resistance. In presence of these two great principles disputing the world, I confess it, I am for the stronger,—that is to say, not for him who triumphs to-day almost everywhere, but for him who will triumph inevitably and definitively to-morrow. Our cause is the holy cause of majorities; and if we wished to translate our thought into a maxim that should sum it up, we should willingly formulate it thus:
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-emph data-origname="emph">
        In politics, that which profits the greatest number possible is good; that which profits only a few, to the detriment of the greatest number, whatever name may be given to it, is evil.
      </tei-emph>
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      I have allowed myself, my friend, to speak to you of principles when I had promised you nothing but history: it is because it is well not to walk at hazard, and to show clearly why, and by what motives, one goes in one direction rather than in another.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      We are, decidedly, revolutionists. Let us not be frightened at words. Let us remember that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jesus Christ</tei-persName> also was called a revolutionist when he brought to the world his doctrine of liberty and equality, and, moreover, was crucified as such (1). The interest of false
    </tei-p>

    <tei-note data-origname="note">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">
        (1) He chose his disciples from the vilest populace; he prefers the slave to the master, the poor man to the rich, the leper to the man in health; all that weeps, all that has wounds, all that is abandoned by the world, is his delight: power, fortune, and happiness are, on the contrary, eternally threatened by him; he overturns all the common notions of morality; he establishes new relations among men, a new law of nations, a new public faith.
      </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">
        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">CHATEAUBRIAND</tei-persName>,
        <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Génie du christianisme</tei-title></tei-bibl>.
      </tei-p>
    </tei-note>

    <tei-pb n="45" facs="v1n7f45" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      gods was but a pretext under which the Roman rulers covered their own interest. They would not have crucified <tei-persName data-origname="persName">the Galilean</tei-persName> had he preached only novelties without consequence; but he was crucified because he said to the master before the slave, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">All flesh is vile</tei-emph>, and to the slave before the master, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">All spirit is divine</tei-emph>, abasing the one by the flesh and raising the other by the spirit; which he completed by these words: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">All men are the children of God; they are all equal before Him.</tei-emph> To which the Man of peace added: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Love one another; that is the law.</tei-emph> All this appeared monstrous to the tamers of men, to the Roman aristocrats, who lived gloriously on the blood and sweat of others. Men were moved. There were men who thought then what has been said in our own day, that nothing was more dangerous than an eloquent proletary. They crucified <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jesus</tei-persName>, the proletary. In truth, I tell you, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Jesus</tei-persName> was, at bottom, more revolutionary than <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Spartacus</tei-persName> himself.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Therefore, as revolutionists, we have reason to rejoice at more than one happy symptom in the general affairs of the world.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      In <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName> reform establishes itself slowly; the work goes on beneath the surface. Among this patient, laborious people much remains, no doubt, to be done, especially for equality; but they are in the right road; and with the liberty of the press, <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName> will know how to conquer also what she lacks,—that is to say, social equality, equality of manners, the first element of democratic societies.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Wellington</tei-persName> ministry will be able to do nothing against progress; it must follow and second the movement, or be vanquished by it. Such is the constant march of things. When it is written that an improvement shall be accomplished, the men most opposed to change are led by Providence to lend their hands to it. Once already <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Wellington</tei-persName> was the instrument of the spirit of justice: it was under his ministry that the emancipation of the Catholics of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Irland</tei-placeName> was obtained and promulgated,—that great reinstatement of an entire population deprived of its political rights because it had a faith of its own. It may happen, perhaps, as then, with regard to reform; and it matters little to the people whether it comes to them from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Wellington</tei-persName> or from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Grey</tei-persName>, provided they obtain it full and entire. The struggle, besides, will be rude; and the old <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">tory</tei-orgName> spirit, which yields only through selfishness, will show itself refractory to concessions until it
      <tei-pb n="46" facs="v1n7f46" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
      is compelled by force; but we trust <tei-persName data-origname="persName">John Bull</tei-persName> to compel it.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      As for the official policy of <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>, I have nothing to tell you: you have seen what a singular ministerial comedy has lately been played; you have seen at work that party of political eunuchs which knows neither how to control power nor how to exercise it. Victory has remained with the doctrinaires. They have the present; but it is the national and patriotic party, which every day acquires new strength, to whom the future belongs; and the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">French colonies</tei-placeName> have the highest interest in its success; for it is by that party alone that the dearest of your wishes and of mine will be accomplished,—the complete and unreserved abolition of slavery,—and the organization of labour upon new bases in our various establishments beyond the seas.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Spain</tei-placeName>, one of the most backward countries of <tei-placeName ref="#EUR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Europe</tei-placeName>, has just entered upon her revolutionary era. The <tei-emph data-origname="emph"><tei-bibl type="legal" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title">Estatuto real</tei-title></tei-bibl></tei-emph>, wrested by the necessities of the time from the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Queen Christina</tei-roleName>, has awakened the new spirit; on every side the provinces have sent to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Madrid</tei-placeName> deputies of the movement; and the Spanish <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Cortes</tei-orgName>, forming two chambers under the denomination of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph"><tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">chambers of procuradores</tei-orgName></tei-emph> and of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph"><tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">proceres</tei-orgName></tei-emph>, apply themselves to the radical reorganization of the country. The reform of minds is accomplished in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Spain</tei-placeName>; it remains to carry it into the laws and into the institutions. The presence of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Don Carlos</tei-persName>, who plays the king in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Navarre</tei-placeName>, pursued and held in check by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mina</tei-persName>, serves only to give more strength—not, we will not say to the party of the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Queen</tei-roleName>, but to the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">national party</tei-orgName>, which is now against legitimacy.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      This poor legitimacy falls almost everywhere before the reason and the will of the age. In <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Portugal</tei-placeName>, however, it has triumphed by the efforts of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Don Pedro</tei-persName>, in the person of his daughter, the young queen <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dona Maria</tei-persName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Miguel</tei-persName> has been definitively driven from the country, and the most rigorous measures have been taken by <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">the chambers</tei-orgName> to prevent his return for ever.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The ex-<tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">king</tei-roleName> now travels like so many others; and all <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Italy</tei-placeName>, where he plays the legitimate prince and the fop, is full of the noise of his bad tone and his matador manners. At <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Genoa</tei-placeName> he has committed pranks and pasquinades in the streets which indicate, on his part, a cerebral lesion.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-pb n="47" facs="v1n7f47" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Whatever may have been the personal sentiments of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Don Pedro</tei-persName>, having been obliged to lean upon the liberals in order to overcome the absolutist obstinacy of his brother, he was necessarily constrained to favour enlightenment, and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Portugal</tei-placeName> has gained much by it. Were it only the advantage of having passed from the tyranny of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Don Miguel</tei-persName> under the power of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dona Maria</tei-persName>, it would already be much. What matters, after that, what <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Don Pedro</tei-persName> really was? Thus goes the world. The least sincere friends of liberty are sometimes forced, by their position, to become its defenders in their own interest; and when they have conquered, and would turn against it—against that which has made them what they are—liberty has taken its place, for good or ill, beside them, and they can no longer drive it wholly away.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      And <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>, in spite of the ill-will of her governors, presides over the movement which carries the world toward liberty! It is because such is the will of the immense majority of the population. It is because <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName> is the first democracy in the world, and because the principle of equality and liberty is more or less in the mind, if not in the heart, of all. The press, besides, by its thousand organs, incessantly subjects every thing to the spirit of examination; prejudices are effaced by its action, and public control is exercised over all powers and all acts, to the great advantage of the country.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      The press relentlessly breaches every thing that tends to thwart the march of the century, and prepares for the world its new destinies. See, too, how it is treated! But persecutions will avail nothing. The press is to-day necessary to social transactions no less than to those of politics; it forms an integral part of our institutions; it is itself an institution,—the most vital of all. Journalism, above all, in spite of the rigours to which it is subjected, pursues its salutary and ascending course. It is not you to whom one must depict the marvellous effects of these intellectual communications, which in a few days carry the same facts to the knowledge of an entire country, and make, at the same moment, upon the same object, thousands of minds think,—minds that tend toward one another in spite of distance, and end by uniting, after mature examination, in a community of just ideas and noble sentiments. Admirable creation of modern times, which renders for ever impossible the return of barbarism, and secures—extending them
      <tei-pb n="48" facs="v1n7f48" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
      every day more and more—the conquests of civilization, of which we are still so far, in spite of our pride, from having reached the last possible term. Let the press and liberty alone, and you will see all the miracles they can bring forth!
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      What shall I tell you also of the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">North</tei-placeName>, that you do not know? On that side there are many crowned heads who are uneasy at seeing us free, and who would like far better to see us hanged.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      To speak frankly, nothing appears to us ended. Hence, in all our hearts, we have I know not what of inquietude; each feels it: it is like a vague dread, a foreboding of conflict that dominates us. Order reigns, it is true; it is still, as in times past, and still everywhere in <tei-placeName ref="#EUR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Europe</tei-placeName>, the twentieth part of the populations that lives at the expense of the rest; for that is what is called order. But it is precisely because this order reigns and cannot endure, that men live in perpetual apprehension of the great revolutionary day which will put an end to it.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      Between <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName>, and all countries of liberty, or even of half-liberty, the alliance is formed; it is secretly seconded by all the peoples who suffer: it remains, then, to know whether the peoples or their oppressors will prevail, and whether the field of the world will remain to the French revolution or to crowned heads. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Nicholas of Russia</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William of Prussia</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Charles-Jean</tei-persName>, the former French Jacobin who bears traced, with powder, on his left arm, this legend: Long live the republic! The wretched renegade dares to be a king! <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Francis of Austria</tei-persName>, and I know not what others who are not worth the honour of being named, flatter themselves that they will conquer the French revolution, the great natural ally of peoples: we take the wager against them; there is little merit in it, besides; it is to wager a hundred thousand against one.
    </tei-p>

    <tei-p data-origname="p">
      If now you put to me this question: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">What will be the future of the world?</tei-emph> I should answer you, no doubt, a little time longer of struggle and the necessary combats; then order with equality, and the universal reconciliation of men within a few years.
                            </tei-p>
                            <tei-p data-origname="p">
                                C.B.
                            </tei-p>
                        </tei-div>
                    </tei-div>
                </tei-div>
        </tei-body>
